question.title: Android proguard, Nullpointer Exception on device

node.contents: I get an exception when I istall my app on the phone. It works without proguard. What is wrong in my configuration? Thank you very much! The config is a default android config i found somwhere. Dont know whats going on

astNode.text: I get an exception when I istall my app on the phone. It works without proguard. What is wrong in my configuration? Thank you very much! The config is a default android config i found somwhere. Dont know whats going on

node.contents: here is my proguard config

astNode.text: here is my proguard config

fragments.text:
configuration file illustrates how to process Android
# applications.
# Usage:
#     java -jar proguard.jar @android.pro
#
# If you're using the Android SDK (version 2.3 or higher), the android tool
# already creates a file like this in your project, called proguard.cfg.
# It should contain the settings of this file, minus the input and output paths
# (-injars, -outjars, -libraryjars, -printmapping, and -printseeds).
# The generated Ant build file automatically sets these paths.

# Specify the input jars, output jars, and library jars.
# Note that

works with Java bytecode (.class),
# before the dex compiler converts it into Dalvik code (.dex).



    # Save the obfuscation mapping to a file, so you can de-obfuscate any stack
    # traces later on.

    -printmapping bin/classes-processed.map

    # You can print out the seeds that are matching the keep options below.

    #-printseeds bin/classes-processed.seeds

    # Preverification is irrelevant for the dex compiler and the Dalvik VM.

    -dontpreverify

    # Reduce the size of the output some more.

    -repackageclasses ''
    -allowaccessmodification

    # Switch off some optimizations that trip older versions of the Dalvik VM.

    -optimizations !code/simplification/arithmetic

    # Keep a fixed source file attribute and all line number tables to get line
    # numbers in the stack traces.
    # You can comment this out if you're not interested in stack traces.

    -renamesourcefileattribute

might need annotations.

    -keepattributes *Annotation*

    # Preserve all fundamental application classes.

    -keep public class * extends

# Preserve all View implementations, their special context constructors, and
    # their setters.

    -keep public class * extends

# The Android Compatibility library references some classes that may not be
    # present in all versions of the API, but we know that's ok.

    -dontwarn android.support.**

    # Preserve all native method names and the names of their classes.

    -keepclasseswithmembernames class * {
        native
# Needed by google-api-client to keep generic types and

node.contents: thank you. didnt help yet, same message :(

astNode.text: thank you. didnt help yet, same message :(

node.contents: If this is not the solution then why is this answer accepted?

astNode.text: If this is not the solution then why is this answer accepted?

node.contents: Try turning off more optimizations that might be blowing up Dalvik. Upon further inspection it looks like you're disabling all optimizations actually.

astNode.text: Try turning off more optimizations that might be blowing up Dalvik. Upon further inspection it looks like you're disabling all optimizations actually.

node.contents: Also try preserving these..

astNode.text: Also try preserving these..

elements.contents:
-keep public class * extends android.app.backup.BackupAgentHelper
-keep public class * extends android.preference.Preference
-keep public class com.android.vending.licensing.ILicensingService

units.rawText:
-keep public class * extends android.app.backup.BackupAgentHelper
-keep public class * extends android.preference.Preference

node.contents: EDIT: Here is my proguard file, wonder if just replacing it will work. Its the default file generated by by ADT so nothing special here.

node.contents: also check out proguardFile proguard-android.txt and proguard-android-optimize.txt which comes as a default with android studio. I use this now as a foundation proguardFile getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android.txt') //-optimize

astNode.text: also check out proguardFile proguard-android.txt and proguard-android-optimize.txt which comes as a default with android studio. I use this now as a foundation proguardFile getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android.txt') //-optimize

node.contents: any update on this .. I am facing the same problem

astNode.text: any update on this .. I am facing the same problem

node.contents: @RajnishMishra and Seb83 I suggest using the workaround by not obfuscating that one class. If there is code that you need to hide it should be possible to move that to classes that are obfuscated. The only part that shouldn't be obfuscated is the dynamic view handling. I'll see if I can make an example project for this issue and do some more checks.

astNode.text: @RajnishMishra and Seb83 I suggest using the workaround by not obfuscating that one class. If there is code that you need to hide it should be possible to move that to classes that are obfuscated. The only part that shouldn't be obfuscated is the dynamic view handling. I'll see if I can make an example project for this issue and do some more checks.

node.contents: I currently have the exact same problem. I have perfectly working code with a custom adapter with layout inflater using the format with parent and false as 2nd and 3rd argument.

astNode.text: I currently have the exact same problem. I have perfectly working code with a custom adapter with layout inflater using the format with parent and false as 2nd and 3rd argument.

node.contents: Since the code runs fine without obfuscation I feel confident enough to ignore all the questions and responses on stackoverflow about null views being returned due to wrong use of the Android API.

astNode.text: Since the code runs fine without obfuscation I feel confident enough to ignore all the questions and responses on stackoverflow about null views being returned due to wrong use of the Android API.

node.contents: If you also have the issue without obfuscation ignore this answer and question and move on! Check these questions

node.contents: I'll do my best to report my findings in this answer. This answer might grow over time. Skip to Conclusion at the bottom if you're eager to know the latest.

astNode.text: I'll do my best to report my findings in this answer. This answer might grow over time. Skip to Conclusion at the bottom if you're eager to know the latest.

node.contents: The Quick and Dirty Solution

astNode.text: The Quick and Dirty Solution

node.contents: Straight forward solution here is to update your proguard configuration to exclude the class your code fails on after obfuscation.

astNode.text: Straight forward solution here is to update your proguard configuration to exclude the class your code fails on after obfuscation.

node.contents: That should look something like this in your proguard config file:

astNode.text: That should look something like this in your proguard config file:

node.contents: For more information on proguard start looking here. Also make sure you have at least the minimal required proguard config file for an Android project. Check this example.

astNode.text: For more information on proguard start looking here. Also make sure you have at least the minimal required proguard config file for an Android project. Check this example.

node.contents: Mapping Back to your Source Code

astNode.text: Mapping Back to your Source Code

node.contents: When looking into this you might be interested in what the original name of that class was before obfuscation. That should make it a lot easier. You can find this mapping in the bin folder of your project in a proguard folder in the mapping.txt file.

astNode.text: When looking into this you might be interested in what the original name of that class was before obfuscation. That should make it a lot easier. You can find this mapping in the bin folder of your project in a proguard folder in the mapping.txt file.

node.contents: Pinned Down to the following lines of code

astNode.text: Pinned Down to the following lines of code

node.contents: In my case I was able to pin down the error on the following lines of codes. These lines were only present in the adapter that failed while other code was common with the working adapters. All of below code is part of the getView(final int position, View convertView, final ViewGroup parent):View method

astNode.text: In my case I was able to pin down the error on the following lines of codes. These lines were only present in the adapter that failed while other code was common with the working adapters. All of below code is part of the getView(final int position, View convertView, final ViewGroup parent):View method

node.contents: If I just remove the addView() and removeAllViews() calls than all goes well.

astNode.text: If I just remove the addView() and removeAllViews() calls than all goes well.

node.contents: Sample Project

astNode.text: Sample Project

node.contents: See https://github.com/hanscappelle/so-10822397 for a sample project. You'll need Android Studio (Beta) 0.8.2 and latest build tools. I also had to manually fetch the proguard-android.txt file and put it in place.

astNode.text: See https://github.com/hanscappelle/so-10822397 for a sample project. You'll need Android Studio (Beta) 0.8.2 and latest build tools. I also had to manually fetch the proguard-android.txt file and put it in place.

node.contents: You can comment out the lines in the adapter that work on the layout field of the static ViewHolder class. Those are the ones that fail once proguard is enabled and the app runs on a device.

astNode.text: You can comment out the lines in the adapter that work on the layout field of the static ViewHolder class. Those are the ones that fail once proguard is enabled and the app runs on a device.

node.contents: Conclusion

astNode.text: Conclusion

node.contents: Seems to be related to dynamically adding views in the getView() method of the custom adapter. That in combination with code obfuscation.

astNode.text: Seems to be related to dynamically adding views in the getView() method of the custom adapter. That in combination with code obfuscation.
